how can i stop other user from using ssh: you could make an ssh group and only allow users in that group to run ssh, or you could use an acl on the ssh binary to forbid a specific user from executing it.
how do i make the ssh group isit the same way as making a group?
yes, it would just be a regular group, then you'd make the ssh binary owned by that group.
how do i make the ssh binary for that group... I really dont know how
it would be something like chown root:ssh /usr/bin/ssh
that would make root the owner and put the file in the ssh group.

as long as you have an ssh group

inst there another way
you need to make the ssh binary not executable by "other" users (ie set the permissions to something like 750)
so that would be sudo chown 750 root:ssh /usr/bin/ssh?
no just chmod 750 /usr/bin/ssh , I assume you've already done the chown'ing.
yah what does 750 mean if you dont mind explaining?
it's rwxr-x---, so rwx for owner, rw for group and nothing for other.
r-x for group, sorry
